### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

  |
9 |   case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  |                                 ^

ex.dfy(9,32): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None
['  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false\n', '  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false\n', '  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false\n', '  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false\n', '  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false\n']
TEXT
### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |
18 |   case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
   |                                                      ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)

TEXT

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
30 |     OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                          ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 

   |
31 |   case _ =>
   |            ^

ex.dfy(31,11): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)

  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>

    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 

   |
27 |   case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
   |                            ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
  case Add(e1, e2) =>

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
30 |     OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                          ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
  case Add(e1, e2) => 
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 
}

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) =>

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => 

   |
26 |   case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

   |                             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

ex.dfy(27,28): Error: missing semicolon at end of statement
   |
28 |   case Add(e1, e2) =>
   |                      ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => {}
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {}
  case Add(e1, e2) => {
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  }
  case _ => {}

   |
32 |   case _ => {}
   |               ^

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => {}
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {}
  case Add(e1, e2) => {
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  }
  case _ => {}
}

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    // recursive call on sub-expressions
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 
    // base case
}

  | Var(name: string)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |

   |                          ^

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e

  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 

   |
31 |   case _ =>
   |            ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ => 
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>

   |
33 |     case _ =>
   |              ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

  |                ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(x: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(x: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(x: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(x: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {

   |
27 |   match e {
   |            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(x: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)

```dafny
datatype Expr =
  | Const(v: int)
  | Var(x: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |
17 |   case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
   |                                                      ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>

   |
30 |   case _ =>
   |            ^

             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => {}
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {}
  case Add(e1, e2) => {
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  }

   |
30 |   }
   |    ^

ex.dfy(30,3): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => {}
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {}
  case Add(e1, e2) => {
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

             | Var(x: string)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  {}

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)

   |
25 |   case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                             ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

ex.dfy(25,28): Error: missing semicolon at end of statement
   |
26 |   case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)
   |                                                 ^

ex.dfy(26,48): Error: invalid UpdateStmt
2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  // Base case: If e is not an addition, then the optimized version of e

   |
29 |   // Base case: If e is not an addition, then the optimized version of e
   |                                                                         ^

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  // Base case: If e is not an addition, then the optimized version of e
  // is just e itself, and the predicate optimal is trivially true for e.

   |
30 |   // is just e itself, and the predicate optimal is trivially true for e.
   |                                                                          ^

             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

  case _ => true

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)

    OptimizerOptimal(e1);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  // Base case: If e is not an addition, then the optimized version of e
  // is just e itself, and the predicate optimal holds for e iff it holds

   |
30 |   // is just e itself, and the predicate optimal holds for e iff it holds
   |                                                                          ^

ex.dfy(30,73): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  // Base case: If e is not an addition, then the optimized version of e
  // is either a constant, a variable, or an addition where at least one
  // of the sub-expressions is not an addition by 0. Thus, it is optimal.

### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  // Base case: If e is not an addition, then the optimized version of e
  // is either a constant, a variable, or an addition where at least one
  // of the sub-expressions has been optimized. But since optimal is
  // defined such that it holds for any expression, it must hold for the

   |

   |                                                                         ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  // Base case: If e is not an addition, then the optimized version of e
  // is either a constant, a variable, or an addition where at least one
  // of the sub-expressions has been optimized. But since optimal is
  // defined to hold for these cases, the lemma follows by structural
  // induction.

             | Var(x: string)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

             | Var(x: string)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);

  // defined to hold for these cases, the lemma follows by structural
  // induction on the shape of the expression.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int)
             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
  case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
  case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
  case _ => e
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e
  case Add(e1, e2) =>
    OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    OptimizerOptimal(e2);
  case _ =>
  end
}
``` package io.github.lucasstarsz.fastj.math.geom;

   |
29 |   end
   |   ^^^

             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

             | Var(x: string)
             | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

    case _ => e

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

case _ => 3

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |
18 |     case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
   |                                                        ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |
30 |       OptimizerOptimal(e1);
   |                            ^

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
31 |       OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                            ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ => 
  }

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) =>

   |

   |                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) = optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) = optimize(e1)

   |
33 |       // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) = optimize(e1)
   |                                                               ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) = optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) = optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case: optimize(Add(e1, e2)) = Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) = optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) = optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case: 
      // optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) = optimal(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)))
      // By definition of optimize

   |
40 |       // By definition of optimize
   |                                   ^

1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) = optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) = optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case: 
      // optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) = optimal(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)))
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case _ => ()
  }
}
```

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) = optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) = optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case: 
      // optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) = optimal(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)))
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case _ => ()
  }
}

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
