### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) = optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) = optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case: 
      // optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2))) = optimal(Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2)))
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case _ => ()
  }
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |

   |                            ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
31 |       OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                            ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>
  }
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>

   |
30 |     case _ =>
   |              ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ => 
  }
}

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ => 

   |
32 |     case _ =>
   |              ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ => 
  }
}

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |
32 |       OptimizerOptimal(e1);
   |                            ^

Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }

case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      // Recursive calls for sub-expressions
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
30 |       OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                            ^

ex.dfy(30,27): Error: rbrace expected

TEXT

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, e2) => 

   |
31 |     case Add(e1, e2) =>
   |                        ^

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

```dafny

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }

      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0

      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      // Recursive case: we optimize the sub-expressions and then we use the lemma recursively

  | Var(name: string)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)

      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)

    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      // Recursive case: we optimize the sub-expressions and then we use the lemma recursively
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ => 
      // Base case: we do nothing as the expression is already optimized

   |
36 |       // Base case: we do nothing as the expression is already optimized
   |                                                                         ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      // Recursive case: we optimize the sub-expressions and then we use the lemma recursively
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ => 
      // Base case: we have a constant or a variable, which are always optimal

```dafny
datatype Expr = 
  | Const(val: int)
  | Var(name: string)
  | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => 
      // In this case, the optimization removes the addition by 0
    case Add(e1, e2) => 
      // Recursive case: we optimize the sub-expressions and then we use the lemma recursively
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ => 
      // Base case: we have a constant or a variable, which are always optimal
  }
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |

   |                                                        ^

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }

   |

   |    ^

  }
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
    case _ => ()

   |
25 |     case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

ex.dfy(25,46): Error: missing semicolon at end of statement
   |
26 |     case _ => ()
   |                 ^

ex.dfy(26,16): Error: invalid Suffix
2 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {

   |                                ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // nothing to optimize, so it's optimal

```dafny

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {

    case Add(Const(0), _) => false

    case _ => e

    case Add(Const(0), _) => false

    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true

    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // nothing to optimize, so it's optimal
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // nothing to optimize, so it's optimal
    }

   |
30 |     }
   |      ^

### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // nothing to optimize, so it's optimal
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // nothing to optimize, so it's optimal
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // recursively prove optimality
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case _ => {

   |
36 |     case _ => {
   |                ^

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)

   |
27 |     case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                                                                   ^

ex.dfy(27,66): Error: invalid UpdateStmt
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
    case _ =>

   |
27 |     case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(i: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), _) => false
    case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
    case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
    case _ => true
  }
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
    case _ =>
  }

   |
27 |     case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)


SCORE
1.0
['\n', '\n', '\n', '\n', '\n']
TEXT

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)

   |
13 |     case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
   |                                           ^

ex.dfy(13,42): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

SCORE
None

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)

   |
14 |     case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
   |                                           ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) =>

   |
24 |     case Add(e1, e2) =>
   |                        ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      // Recursive case: e is an addition.
      // Optimize its sub-expressions and then apply the lemma recursively.
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>
      // Base case: e is not an addition.

   |
30 |       // Base case: e is not an addition.
   |                                          ^

ex.dfy(30,41): Error: rbrace expected

TEXT

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      // Recursive case: e is an addition.
      // Optimize its sub-expressions and then apply the lemma recursively.
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>
      // Base case: e is not an addition.
      // Since optimize doesn't change non-addition expressions,
      // the result is optimal if the original expression is optimal.

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      // Recursive case: e is an addition.
      // Optimize its sub-expressions and then apply the lemma recursively.
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>
      // Base case: e is not an addition.
      // Since optimize doesn't change non-addition expressions,
      // the result of optimize(e) is the same as e, and thus optimal.

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e

}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      // Recursive case: e is an addition.
      // Optimize its sub-expressions and then apply the lemma recursively.
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>
      // Base case: e is not an addition.
      // Since optimize doesn't change non-addition expressions,
      // the result of optimize(e) is also optimal.

   |
32 |       // the result of optimize(e) is also optimal.
   |                                                    ^

ex.dfy(32,51): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      // Recursive case: e is an addition.
      // Optimize its sub-expressions and then apply the lemma recursively.
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>
      // Base case: e is not an addition.
      // Since optimize doesn't change non-addition expressions,
      // the resulting expression is also optimal.

   |
32 |       // the resulting expression is also optimal.
   |                                                   ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
28 |       OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                            ^

TEXT

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) =>
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) =>
    case Add(e1, e2) =>
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    case _ =>
  }
}

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Recursive call for e2
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
26 |       OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                            ^

ex.dfy(26,27): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)

    case _ => e
  }

### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Recursive call for e2
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Recursive call for e1
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Recursive call for e1 and e2
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);

   |
35 |       OptimizerOptimal(e2);
   |                            ^

ex.dfy(35,27): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {

      // Recursive call for e1

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Recursive call for e2
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Recursive call for e1
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Recursive call for e1 and e2
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case _ => ()
  }
}
``` package com.github.kristofa.brave;

   |
38 |   }
   |   ^

   |               ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)

   |
24 |     case Add(e1, e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e1); OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                                                                   ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // The lemma holds because the optimizer removes additions by 0.

   |
25 |       // The lemma holds because the optimizer removes additions by 0.
   |                                                                       ^

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)

    case _ => e
  }

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) == optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) == optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }

   |
33 |     }
   |      ^

```dafny

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{

    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {

      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }

      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) == optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);

      // Inductive case: optimize(Add(e1, e2)) == Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) == optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) == optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case:
      // Assume optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);

   |
37 |       OptimizerOptimal(e1);
   |                            ^

ex.dfy(37,27): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

  ensures optimal(optimize(e))

  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) == optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) == optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case:
      // Assume optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
      // Need to show: optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2)))
      // By definition of optimize and the inductive hypothesis
    }
    case _ => {
      // Base case: e is not an addition

   |
41 |       // Base case: e is not an addition
   |                                         ^

ex.dfy(41,40): Error: rbrace expected
1 parse errors detected in ex.dfy

None

### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:

  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true

### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as

case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) == optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {

      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);

    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case:
      // Assume optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
      // Need to show: optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2)))
      // By definition of optimize and the inductive hypothesis
    }
    case _ => {
      // Base case: if e is not an addition, optimize(e) == e

   |
41 |       // Base case: if e is not an addition, optimize(e) == e
   |                                                              ^

  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(Const(0), e2)) == optimize(e2)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e2);
    }
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => {
      // Base case: optimize(Add(e1, Const(0))) == optimize(e1)
      // By definition of optimize
      OptimizerOptimal(e1);
    }
    case Add(e1, e2) => {
      // Inductive case:
      // Assume optimal(optimize(e1)) and optimal(optimize(e2))
      // Need to show: optimal(optimize(Add(e1, e2)))
      // By definition of optimize and the inductive hypothesis
    }
    case _ => {
      // Base case: e is not an addition
      // By definition of optimal
    }
  }
}

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(val: int) | Var(name: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}

lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
{
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => 

   |
24 |     case Add(Const(0), e2) => OptimizerOptimal(e2)
   |                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

ex.dfy(24,30): Error: missing semicolon at end of statement
   |
25 |     case Add(e1, Const(0)) => OptimizerOptimal(e1)
   |                               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

ex.dfy(25,30): Error: missing semicolon at end of statement
   |
26 |     case Add(e1, e2) =>
   |                        ^

ex.dfy(26,23): Error: rbrace expected

['  ensures optimal(optimize(e))\n', '  ensures optimal(optimize(e))\n', '  ensures optimal(optimize(e))\n', '  ensures optimal(optimize(e))\n', '  ensures optimal(optimize(e))\n']
['{\n', '{\n', '{\n', '{\n', '{\n']

### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))

   |
15 |     case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
   |                                                        ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }

   |
17 |   }
   |    ^

### Spec: In Dafny, write an ADT for arithmetic expressions comprising constants, variables and binary addition. Then write a predicate `optimal` that holds on an expression if it has no additions by 0. Then write an optimizer `optimize` that removes all additions by 0. Then write a lemma `OptimizerOptimal` that ensures `optimal(optimize(e))` for all expressions `e`.
### Hint: This is the definiton of the `optimal` predicate:
predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}
### Hint: Don't use the same structure for `optimize` as for `optimal`. Instead, follow the next hint.
### Hint: In the addition case, the `optimize` function should recursively optimize the sub-expressions and then match on the optimized sub-expressions.
### Hint: Do NOT use `requires` anywhere.
### Hint: Write the lemma as
lemma OptimizerOptimal(e: Expr)
  ensures optimal(optimize(e))
### Hint: Recall that in Dafny, pattern match takes the form
match e
case Foo(x, y) => 1
case Bar(x) => 2
case _ => 3
### Hint: For the proof, just do a simple pattern match (match not if) and call the lemma recursively without adding asserts.

```dafny
datatype Expr = Const(n: int) | Var(x: string) | Add(e1: Expr, e2: Expr)

predicate optimal(e: Expr) {
  match e
  case Add(Const(0), _) => false
  case Add(_, Const(0)) => false
  case Add(e1, e2) => optimal(e1) && optimal(e2)
  case _ => true
}

function optimize(e: Expr): Expr {
  match e {
    case Add(Const(0), e2) => optimize(e2)
    case Add(e1, Const(0)) => optimize(e1)
    case Add(e1, e2) => Add(optimize(e1), optimize(e2))
    case _ => e
  }
}
